newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU probing software distribution practices.
newsitem.headline: EU probing software distribution practices.

text.p: The European Union's competition chief, Karel Van Miert, said on Wednesday he was investigating complaints of anti-competitive software distribution practices in the EU.
"We are looking into some of these cases," he said at a news conference.

Despite repeated questions, Van Miert refused to give any details. But he has previously said the European Commission was investigating a complaint about the pricing practices of U.S. software giant Microsoft Corp.
That complaint was filed more than a year ago by the Personal Computer Association in Britain, which said on Wednesday it was getting impatient for results.
"We're rather frustrated that we have had no satisfactory advance from the Commission on this matter," PCA executive director Keith Warburton told Reuters.

The PCA charges Microsoft with abusing its dominant position in its pricing practices, when selling the MS Office software package to personal computer manufacturers who want to "bundle" it into the machines they sell.
It says Microsoft charges a handful of key customers, including U.S. computer maker Gateway 2000, much lower prices than it charges the rest of its customers.
"The result of this is that Microsoft as a monopoly supplier is restricting the availability of a monopoly product," Warburton said.
When asked about the complaint last year by a British European Parliament deputy, Graham Watson, Van Miert responded that he was discussing the charges with Microsoft.

"The extent to which Microsoft, which appears to be a dominant supplier, can charge different prices for different customers, and other aspects of their license contracts with computer manufacturers, are currently being discussed with Microsoft's management," he said in a written response.
"The answer I got was not terribly satisfying," Watson told Reuters. "The Commission said, we will look into it."
The complaint is not the first time the Commission has scrutinised Microsoft. It said last year it was studying the impact on competition of Microsoft's online service, the Microsoft Network.
It also cooperated with the U.S. Justice Department in an investigation that resulted in a 1994 settlement under which Microsoft ended certain licensing practices that were seen to harm competition.
Microsoft officials in Europe were unavailable for comment.
